ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 3-4 hrs
6 hours
15hours
10 hours
ABOUT FIVE TO SIX HOURS
five days. honestly. especially when there is a project
Anywhere between 5 hours to over 24 hours (looking at you, SAS project)
5 hours
Over 15 hours.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: It is a good introductory course to programming with SAS and R. Workload is not heavy. But the projects are a bit tedious. The grading of this course is not so generous though.

I think this was a great class. One comment that I have is that I felt that there was a stark difference between the difficulty of the SAS section and the difficulty of the R session. Obviously this is just my opinion but I have about the same level of familiarity with the two programs. I found that for the R assignment I had to spend a lot more time learning functions that weren't in the notes than I did for the SAS assignments. I guess one recommendation I have would be to spend more time covering basic R functions and leave out the final lecture (which was interesting but I would have appreciated front-loading with more information that would help us do the assignments). Also, I felt that the difficulty of the homeworks escalated dramatically from the lectures - going from simulating coin tosses (pretty clear, very intuitive) in class to simulating election results felt like a dramatic jump in complexity. Perhaps the lectures could cover material that is more closely the same level of complexity as the homeworks (for the R section)... Otherwise this was a great course!!

Strength: you get to learn the details of working in SAS and R that are not really useful unless you plan to go into biostatistics Weakness: Poorly taught, assignments/projects are poorly worded, grades are very inconsistent with directions given, instructor assumes students know how to work with R and assigns things that were not covered in class

productive skills in learning SAS and R programming. Strength: organized programming notes which allowed self-learning if I missed something in class. Also good explanation during class of logic in code. Challenges: homework assignment and examinations not necessarily directly related to skills learned in programming class. A lot of it required some element in ingenuity to figure out what was desired and thus resulted in much time being spent working on homework assignments.

The course could be structured more clear. Some of the concepts are hard and the instructor should give students more time to learn. The difficulty level of each homework is also very different. Some assignments are really hard.

The course is very helpful for learning to program in SAS. The R portion could be improved as it was much more difficult and some students had less background in R than SAS. The projects were massive and difficult and grading was pretty harsh
strengths: covered a lot of information, weaknesses: hard to see the programming code, should not be called "advanced," level was like for beginners/intermediate
The grading is weird
Teach Basic SAS and R systematically There are still a lot more we didnt learn

Strengths: Learned many essential skills to be a basic programmer in SAS and R Weaknesses: grading felt arbitrary and harsh, assignment prompt was very general but points were taken off for such specific things that were not mentioned in prompt, for the R portion of the class, the assignments did not reflect what we learned in class Suggestions: provide a grading rubric for each assignment, allow some room to code in a different way the professor might code something if the outcome is correct.
Strengths: Exposure to a variety of features and functions of SAS and R. Weaknesses: Class may be difficult for those who do not already have experience in SAS and R.
The class is useful for learning programming. spend too much time on homework

Strengths: I liked the format of this class. It differed from AAMIE in that the code was right in front of me (to run and annotate), as we were in lecture. This vastly improves learning these statistical programs. I also think there is value in learning to code efficiently, and to know the basics of more than one program. Weaknesses: I felt that the second half of the class (R) was rushed, and focused on different things. Rather than learning the same methods, but in R, we did a lot more simulations and the second project was much more ambiguous than the first. To aid in faster grading, maybe it would be better to have the projects be in groups. Also, the assignments could have benefited from a rubric. You could complete an assignment according to the instructions, but still get an arbitrary number of points off for efficiency or something else unexpected.
This course systematically taught us all the programming knowledge about SAS and R. It is very conducive class for learning big data cleaning and analysis.
The course material is well-organized and helpful.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Denise Esserman  Strength: she is very clear and well-organized. I could understand everything in the lectures. She is approachable for questions as well. Weakness: the grading is a bit strict.
Instructor: Denise Esserman  Denise was great! Very responsive and helpful and flexible with office hours. I really enjoyed working with her.

Instructor: Denise Esserman  The instructor's delivering was fine, but the grading was late, so timely feedback was hopeless. I think the instructor should be more clear on what she expects from the student. I was often getting points off for things not stated in the assignment. It was obvious that students will discuss the approach towards writing the code but you can get many points off for a really small mistake, which is understandable but is a poor reflection of what students actually learn from the course. The amount of points taken off should reflect the fixability of the error. Additionally, the instructor stated that she will only accept universal codes, meaning there should be no error in the code when she ran it. However, the class note code that was prepared by the instructor was also prone to error. There had been many times that I could not run her code and could only saw her doing it on her computer. And I was not alone. If that's the case, it seemed unfair for her to ask the students to provide universal code. I understand that if the code didn't run on her computer, she couldn't grade. But it's only fair that she show some empathy and understand that this was not the student's intention, and it actually ran perfectly well on the student's computer.

Instructor: Denise Esserman  Nice in person, office hour setting Her teaching needs to improve to actually cover the materials that she will assign to students for big projects Directions given in projects/assignments are very vague and poorly worded with no sense of detail/guidance; this leads to students having to make corrections (we get 6-8 updates per project) by the deadline time nears, which is very inefficient use of our time Grading is very slow and we got our "midterm" project graded back by the end of semester (when we had to turn in our "final" project) Grades inconsistently and docks chunks of points for things(coding) that she deem "inefficient." Since there are no clear directions given in each assignment, students do not know how her grading guideline can be so strict If you do not have experience in R and plan to learn it through this class, do not!
Instructor: Denise Esserman  effective in explanation of programming logic

Instructor: Denise Esserman  Her teaching is very fast. And the office hour is short. The instructor could be more patient and learn to understand student's need. Also, the grading is too strict. It's not understandable to take off 20 points for just a typo. It's a way of denying student's actual work and only focusing on code style. Some of the homework took a lot of time to write. And if a simple typo can cost 20 points deduction, it's like if I did the homework for nothing. The instructor should really learn to understand students and improve her teaching and grading.
Instructor: Denise Esserman  Super nice in office hours, class demeanor could be improved a little.
Instructor: Denise Esserman  strengths: very knowledgable, great office hours, helpful over email as well weaknesses: would have liked to spend more time on advanced concepts
Instructor: Denise Esserman  The grading is weird
Instructor: Denise Esserman  Explain concepts clearly SAS and R projects she gave were poorly formulated, require repetitive explanation and confirmation

Instructor: Denise Esserman  Professor Esserman was a good teacher in the class room and helpful in office hours one-on-one. Everything she taught in class was taught clearly, and her notes in the code were thorough. However, my issue comes in with the assignments and the grading. In the R portion of the class, the assignments were well beyond what was ever taught in class. For instance, the class lecture would go over a simple example of simulations but the assignment would ask for something so much more complicated than what we learned in class. Furthermore, the assignment would be so much more complicated that it wasn't something we could apply the class notes to as we could for the SAS portion of the class. The grading was very confusing as we often got points off for things that were never expressed in the actual assignment. Although I learned a lot in this class, I think my grade unfairly suffered because of the points I mentioned above.
Instructor: Denise Esserman  Lecture is pretty dry, just following along with the code she has previously written. More open and willing to help in office hours.

Instructor: Denise Esserman  Strength: Instructor prepare clear slides and class notes. Office hour is very useful. weakness: she is a very tough grader. We work so hard to generate the coding. She took 30points on a little mistake. She took the spelling mistake for 25 points. The full points is 100. Homework is so hard for programming beginner. The difficulty level is much higher than the class notes especially for the project.

Instructor: Denise Esserman  Denise is overall a good lecturer. She has clearly annotated notes and projects her voice well in lecture. Everything was well organized and neat. During office hours, she was very helpful and nice if we didn't understand how to move forward with an assignment. However, I would suggest a quick break in the middle of lecture. It is difficult to sit through 2 hours of lecture without losing focus. It would be great if we took five minutes or if there was two shorter lectures a week. Also, the console in R studio can be moved so that it is not at the bottom of the screen. It is virtually impossible to see if you are anywhere besides the front. Speaking of which, it is really hard to get a seat and get situated with all the files when there is a class exactly before ours and people don't leave. Five minutes grace period to get logged in (or just getting a temp check "are you guys ready?") would also be great.

Instructor: Denise Esserman  Professor Esserman is very good at explainning and teaching coding. We really like that she put notes into the codes, which helps us to review the codes for our homework and projoct. She is very patient for answering our questions.

Instructor: Denise Esserman  I love the instructor. She is every organized and logical when preparing for the course material and answering questions. The assignments are described clearly in detail. The feedback is clear and reasonable.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Good course.
Unsure if the instructor will curve for the grade. The content is useful, but the grading sucks. Take the course if you want to learn SAS and R. Don't take the course if you care about the grade.
There are things you learn about SAS and R here and there, but I would not recommend this class to someone outside of biostats or someone experienced with using R

Class for learning advanced SAS and basic R skills. Useful for learning programming languages but not for running statistical testing (we do not cover stats in this class). Homework assignments can take a long time, they are difficult and require some element of ingenuity to figure out sometimes.
This course is useful but you have to learn all by yourself.
Its fine if youre willing to put a decent amount of effort/ work in
good class if you are new to programming
Useful programming course

I am not sure how to recommend this course to a fellow student. My gut is to recommend this course to a student who has advanced skills in R so that they would be able to get through the assignments, but then again the student would probably be too bored in class. Overall, the class itself was useful, but the assignments and grading were very frustrating to deal with.

Intermediate level SAS and R programming class. Helpful, but you will end up just looking things up on StackOverflow, as some of the things required to complete assignments are not gone over in class.
Yes I will recommend to other student. It is still useful for doing internship in the future.

As a non-biostats student taking this course, I think that this was a good exercise at being better at programming in SAS/R. You did not need an extensive amount of biostats knowledge (except for the R project). I would recommend this course, but only if you have time. Your code may not always work out, so it is important not to do the assignments last minute. Overall, good class, glad I took it.
Strongly recommend to everybody!
I would recommend this course to others, because I think the material is useful and students can learn a lot from this course.
